ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments:
This syllabus changed my life. Milton, Flaubert, and Woolf have changed the way I view love. Proust has changed the way I write. Frankenstein has changed the way I view having children. Don Quixote has changed the way I see myself. Hadji Murat has changed the way I see war. 
Proust! Read Proust!

I acquired a broad understanding of and appreciation for some of the most seminal texts in Western literature. DS is a gem. In this program, you learn more than you'd have thought was possible to learn in four years, much less in one. Take DS. Take the leap of faith.
Professor Soles offers a clear, methodical approach to writing literature essays---this is the class to properly learn to write your 5-page argumentative essay.
Close reading, higher level analysis of literary themes
How to analyze texts comparatively with emphasis on the anxiety of influence and meta textual analysis; how to read for personal fulfillment and identity
Speaking in class; academic paper writing
This course was wonderful for learning how to write an academic essay. What was best, however, was the seminars discussing the works.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: STRENGTHS: Professor Soles' Hamlet reading. The syllabus. WEAKNESSES: Professor Soles is a genius, but sometimes seminar felt more like lecture than seminar. Sometimes he came in with a particular sections we would close read which made reading the whole text seem like an unnecessary task (particular to Milton). I think Soles could give the students a bit more speaking times, and allow us to lead the seminar vibe. Also feedback was incredibly extensive and more comprehensive than any other DS track, but it took many, many weeks to receive it.
The reading is somewhat onerous, and, from time to time, it will detract from your ability to interact with and fully grasp the texts. Otherwise, DS is flawless.

Strengths: essay writing, feedback, clear interest in students, office hours.
Weaknesses: class discussions can feel fake, pretentions, sometimes it feels like Professor Soles is only looking for one right answer even though discussions about literature should not have only one right answer.
Overall very good, Professor could work to appear more genuine

The themes of imagination, desire, and freedom were coherent throughout the whole course, which was an incredible framing of otherwise disparate texts. Some texts, particularly Hadji Murat, Omeros, and Raisin, were not contextualised enough.
I enjoyed class discussion and discussion posts.

Strengths of this course lie in discussions with classmates who read the text from all different perspectives, and the seminars teach you to advance your critical thinking. The structure of seminar is really important to creating a learning environment conducive to conversation that involves the majority of the class rather than just a few individuals speaking for most of the time, and I think that could be improved upon.

Strengths: wonderful seminar, probably the best out of the three DS courses
Weakness: Book selections were sometimes strange, like Raisin on the Sun and Petrarch

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: DO NOT DROP DS. The ancients are over. It is time to have your life changed. This syllabus changed my life. I used to see literature through the world. Now I see the world through literature. Also WOOLF AND PROUST!!!!!!!! Please trust the process and take second sem DS. For Soles' semianr, I wrote some stuff in the strengths and weaknesses section.

How can you leave Yale satisfied, as a first-year, if you didn't take DS? The answer is simple: you cannot. DS is a personally fulfilling, academically thrilling, emotionally trying, and radically life-altering program. It will push you past your limits and unleash what was previously undiscovered potential. Do it. Take the leap of faith. Trust the program to guide you through your first year. You will not regret it. (And if you do regret it, which you won't, you can always drop second semester).

I would recommend prof. Soles to students who want to not only read the DS texts, but also learn about the nature of writing literature. Also take this class if you are looking for a very personal approach.
Yes - Soles style can be very off putting but he is a smart and passionate professor from whom you will learn a lot
If youre thinking of dropping DS second semester, dont do it. You will learn so much and have so much fun.
Yes

Yes! I personally really enjoyed reading the more modern texts, and I think that this course does a great job building a literary foundation to situate each work in. A lot of the course is up to how much you want to put in to reading and discussing the works, and I think that the literature track can be more personally moving than the other tracks.
Yes, this course reignited my love for literary discussion.
